image.altText: Joe Biden smiles while sitting infront of a US flag in a conference room.

items.synopsis: The White House says US President Joe Biden has postponed his planned trip to Australia and will return home after the G7 in Japan because of stalled domestic debt ceiling negotiations.

title.children: Joe Biden postpones planned trip to Australia due to US debt ceiling crisis

image.altText: A man holds open an empty wallet.

items.synopsis: Younger Australians are being forced to change their behaviour to deal with the rising cost of living, a report based on the financial data of 7 million people shows.

title.children: Cutting back due to the cost-of-living crunch? Not everyone is

image.altText: Three firefighters stand outside in the dark in Wellington with one being sprayed with sprinklers

items.synopsis: A devastating fire ravaged through a hostel in New Zealand's capital early Tuesday morning, taking the lives of at least six people. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: What we know about the Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: Special needs young people in wheelchairs.

items.synopsis: New data reveals that, while remote regions have attracted the highest average plan value, participants in those postcodes spend less due to restricted service provision.

title.children: NDIS participants missing out on services due to provider shortage

image.altText: A bald shirtless man faces a white wall, his back is covered in elaborate tattoos

items.synopsis: Harusan felt he had little choice in life but to follow his father's footsteps and become a Japanese gangster. It was a path that landed him in jail for years, but now, he is ready to fight Russian invaders on the front line in Ukraine.

title.children: After leaving jail, Harusan bought a one-way ticket to Ukraine to start a new life as a soldier

image.altText: a husband and wife stand arm-in-arm with bleak expressions in front of an unfinished home

items.synopsis: Mali wanted to achieve the "great Australian dream" of owning her own home. It turned into a nightmare when one of the country's largest builders collapsed.

title.children: 'Unbelievably hard': Families left in limbo after collapse of Porter Davis

image.altText: A man with short salt and pepper coloured hair and slight beard stands in front of a stone wall

items.synopsis: While New Zealanders have welcomed easier, cheaper pathways to gain Australian citizenship, some say they were left in the dark about plans to abolish an expensive visa that will soon be redundant.

title.children: Rob paid $4,000 for a visa that will soon be 'redundant' — and he's not the only one

image.altText: A worker inspects solar panels at a solar farm in China.

items.synopsis: For millions of Australians, solar panels have been a ticket to cheap, clean power. But researchers and human rights activists warn there's a dark side to their supply and changes are needed.

title.children: 'Dark underbelly': The hidden human toll behind Australia's love affair with cheap solar panels

image.altText: Israel Folau points to the sky with both hands and looks up in a blue rugby shirt

items.synopsis: His contributions to rugby league and union are beyond reproach, however his sacking from the Wallabies after expressing his religious beliefs sparked a debate that continues to polarise to this day.

title.children: Footy, family and faith: How Israel Folau became the most controversial figure in Australian sport

image.altText: Heather smiling in her home

items.synopsis: A housing program is cutting people's energy bills and keeping people warmer in Victoria's winter months as many struggle with health issues due to poorly insulated homes.

title.children: Heather used to be embarrassed to have guests in her cold home. Now she has no shortage of visitors

image.altText: A person seen in silhouette wearing army gear as orange flames and fire burns from debris.

items.synopsis: Moscow had touted the Kinzhal as a next-generation hypersonic missile that was all but unstoppable. Off the battlefield, Ukraine has detained the head of its Supreme Court on corruption allegations.

title.children: Ukraine says it shot down Russian hypersonic missiles but Russia denies the claim

image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Police review NZ hostel fire CCTV, and rapper Slowthai denies rape charges. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police in New Zealand's capital Wellington say they anticipate they will be able to enter the scene of yesterday's deadly hostel fire in the coming hours. At least six people are confirmed to have died following the blaze at Loafers Lodge in the suburb of Newtown, but others remain unaccounted for. The scene is set to be handed to police by Fire and Emergency New Zealand, after "an extensive health and safety assessment and the mitigation of any identified risks". Acting Wellington District Commander, Inspector Dion Bennett, says entering the building is a "critical step" in the police investigation. Police say they will be "unable to provide any definitive comment on the number of deceased" until the scene is extensively examined. "We know this is an incredibly difficult time for those waiting for information regarding family members and friends who may have been staying at Loafers Lodge at the time of the fire," Bennett says. "I want to reassure everyone impacted by the fire that we will work as quickly as we can to provide the answers you need. "We have a large number of staff dedicated to this operation, with specialist staff being brought into Wellington from around the country to assist." Bennett says police will be talking to evacuated residents again today, and have already secured and reviewed CCTV footage from the area around the hostel. "Work is also ongoing to determine who was in the building at the time of the fire and who remains unaccounted for or uncontactable," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand police review CCTV from deadly Wellington hostel fire, will examine site today

props.alt: Emergency vehicles outside a hostel building, which has fire marks on its exterior

children.content: (Reuters: Lucy Craymer)
Police in New Zealand's capital Wellington say they anticipate they will be able to enter the scene of yesterday's deadly hostel fire in the coming hours.
At least six people are confirmed to have died
following the blaze at Loafers Lodge in the suburb of Newtown, but
others remain unaccounted for
The scene is set to be handed to police by Fire and Emergency New Zealand, after "an extensive health and safety assessment and the mitigation of any identified risks".
Acting Wellington District Commander, Inspector Dion Bennett, says entering the building is a "critical step" in the police investigation.
Police say they will be
"unable to provide any definitive comment on the number of deceased" until the scene is extensively examined
"We know this is an incredibly difficult time for those waiting for information regarding family members and friends who may have been staying at Loafers Lodge at the time of the fire," Bennett says.
"I want to reassure everyone impacted by the fire that we will work as quickly as we can to provide the answers you need.
"We have a large number of staff dedicated to this operation, with specialist staff being brought into Wellington from around the country to assist."
Bennett says police will be talking to evacuated residents again today, and have
already secured and reviewed CCTV footage
from the area around the hostel.
"Work is also ongoing to determine who was in the building at the time of the fire and who remains unaccounted for or uncontactable," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Falls Festival has announced it's taking a break this summer. The travelling festival that frequents Fremantle, Melbourne and Byron Bay over the new year released a statement this morning. "After an impressive 28 years ringing in the New Year with some of the world’s biggest acts, the Falls team are today switching on their OOOs and taking this New Years’ season off to rest, recover and recalibrate," it says. "We send huge love and appreciation to all our patrons for their ongoing support and for the great vibes they brought to the 2022/23 events." After being postponed for two years because of COVID-19, Falls Festival returned for the 2023 New Year in Byron Bay, Fremantle and the Melbourne CBD. It started in 1993 in the coastal Victorian town of Lorne. Organisers say they will provide an update on their future plans when the time is right.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: There will be no Falls Festival this year

children.content: Falls Festival has announced it's taking a break this summer.
The travelling festival that frequents Fremantle, Melbourne and Byron Bay over the new year released a statement this morning.

"After an impressive 28 years ringing in the New Year with some of the world’s biggest acts, the Falls team are today switching on their OOOs and taking this New Years’ season off to rest, recover and recalibrate," it says.
"We send huge love and appreciation to all our patrons for their ongoing support and for the great vibes they brought to the 2022/23 events."
After being postponed for two years because of COVID-19, Falls Festival returned for the 2023 New Year in Byron Bay, Fremantle and the Melbourne CBD.
It started in 1993 in the coastal Victorian town of Lorne.
Organisers say they will provide an update on their future plans when the time is right.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Royal Children's Hospital's chief executive Bernadette McDonald has provided an update on a school bus crash which took place west of Melbourne yesterday afternoon. The bus carrying 45 children had just left Exford Primary School when it was hit by a truck around 4pm. McDonald says the hospital had nine patients arrive yesterday and two have since been discharged, leaving seven children still in a serious condition. She says some have suffered traumatic injuries. "We admitted seven patients, one of those is in our intensive care unit at the moment," McDonald says. "The ages of the children range from five to 11 years old. "The children have suffered multiple and traumatic injuries, including partial and complete amputations of arms, multiple crushed limb injuries, severe lacerations to head and body, head injuries, classified injuries and creations that currently receiving spinal support and being monitored carefully in terms of spinal injuries."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Melbourne school bus crash victims have suffered spinal injuries and some required amputations

props.alt: A woman in a glasses and scarf gives a press conference outside a hospital

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Royal Children's Hospital's chief executive Bernadette McDonald has provided an update on a school bus crash which took place west of Melbourne yesterday afternoon.
The bus carrying 45 children
had just left Exford Primary School when it was hit by a truck around 4pm.
McDonald says the hospital had nine patients arrive yesterday and two have since been discharged, leaving seven children still in a serious condition.
She says some have suffered traumatic injuries.
"We admitted seven patients, one of those is in our intensive care unit at the moment," McDonald says.
"The ages of the children range from five to 11 years old.

"The children have suffered multiple and traumatic injuries, including partial and complete amputations of arms, multiple crushed limb injuries, severe lacerations to head and body, head injuries, classified injuries and creations that currently receiving spinal support and being monitored carefully in terms of spinal injuries."

image.altText: A man with grey hair with a fireman's hat behind him

items.synopsis: Despite being gradually phased out, the toxic chemicals are still found in products like household cookware, waterproof jackets, stain resistant carpets and food packaging, experts say.

title.children: 'It's in everyone's blood': Australian government urged to ban PFAS chemicals amid health concerns

image.altText: A man kneeling down on a footpath next to his dog.

items.synopsis: They were marketed for their silence, but now the blind and low-vision community are calling for fake noises to be attached to electric vehicles.

title.children: Electric cars were originally marketed for their silence but vision-impaired Australians want them to be noisier

image.altText: Reef rebuilding project helping marine life thrive

items.synopsis: Early settlers who fished native reefs with rakes and chains left them devoid of marine life but a project in Tasmania is the latest example of how the tide is being turned many years later.

title.children: How do you build a reef? Rocks, baby oysters used as reef starter to bring back life

image.altText: People move from their homes to take shelter in the nearest cyclone shelter.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people, including Rohingya Muslims, are feared dead after a cyclone rocks Myanmar, as rescue efforts are hampered by damage to infrastructure.

title.children: Hundreds feared dead, including Rohingya Muslims, after cyclone Mocha

image.altText: Bone disc on an X-ray of someone's hands

items.synopsis: During the Cold War, the Soviet government banned jazz, rock 'n' roll and other music. A group of bootleggers came up with an unusual way to distribute the music they loved.

title.children: Stephen was intrigued when he found an X-ray record at a Russian market. What he discovered inspired him

image.altText: A wooden carving depicting a woman

items.synopsis: Art Gallery of New South Wales has returned an 800-year-old wooden carving to the Nepalese temple it was taken from, but after 20 years of work, and with so many more stolen pieces in their collection, experts say more needs to be done.

title.children: Sydney gallery returns stolen Nepalese carving, despite knowing for 20 years it was stolen

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff with a football.

items.synopsis: As the game involving the political football — aka Hobart's AFL stadium — enters what could be the final quarter, Tasmania may find itself facing a constitutional crisis, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Opponents to the Hobart AFL stadium have a 'nuclear option' in next week's budget

image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

items.synopsis: The South Australian government will spearhead a national review into the origins of First Nations artwork following allegations non-Indigenous workers have interfered in works by Aboriginal artists.

title.children: South Australian government to probe 'serious allegations' of interference in Aboriginal art

image.altText: Close up of a Tasmania Police cap.

items.synopsis: Australia is experiencing a shortage of police officers, with some states embarking on overseas recruitment drives and one state trying to sign people up at football games.

title.children: Police recruitment crisis putting officers and community 'at risk'

image.altText: Jennie and Ray give smile deeply at each other in an open-top car. They are in wedding dress and suit.

items.synopsis: WA is significantly expanding the number of unsolved missing and murdered persons cases where a $1 million reward is on offer for information that results in a conviction.

title.children: Raymond and Jennie Kehlet mystery among 64 WA cold cases to attract $1 million rewards

image.altText: Collingwood Magpies players huddle together during a Super Netball game.

items.synopsis: The future of the Collingwood Magpies Super Netball team is up in the air, with the club in grave danger of folding due to financial woes.

title.children: Collingwood Magpies Super Netball team in danger of folding

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: There are at least four things that would do more to restrain rents than Labor’s $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund – and one of them would do it a lot quicker, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Restrict negative gearing — and three other ways to bring down rent and build houses faster than Labor's $10b fund

image.altText: Keys rang from lock, in a front door.

items.synopsis: The chief executive of the Real Estate Institute of Australia says a solution to the rental crisis is to make better use of existing houses and to build more.

title.children: Councils called to push landlords to make vacant or holiday homes available for renters

image.altText: RBA building

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns further interest rate increases are still possible, as a former RBA governor says the low-rate era is over, leaving households feeling like Australia is heading for recession.

title.children: House price rebound appears to have clinched RBA rate rise in May, minutes reveal

image.altText: Katy, a middle-aged woman in a salmon-pink top, sits at a table looking serious

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians sell investment properties, refinance mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: A transcript of closed proceedings during the trial of Bruce Lehrmann, which has been released to an ACT board of inquiry, reveals the jury never discussed the research paper that saw the case abandoned.

title.children: Prohibited research that caused Lehrmann trial to be abandoned was never discussed by jury, transcript reveals

image.altText: Victoria, who has shoulder-length blonde hair, looks calmly at the camera in a close-up portrait.

items.synopsis: On the day former police officer Brett Johnson is sentenced for abusing his position of power to pursue vulnerable women, one of his victims speaks exclusively to the ABC about the devastating impact his offending had on her life.

title.children: A police officer's misconduct shattered Victoria's life. He has now been jailed for six months

image.altText: A young woman with shoulder-length dark hair looking straight ahead.

items.synopsis: Robert and Anne Geeves, who were living with 19-year-old Amber Haigh at the time of her disappearance in June 2002, have been committed to stand trial on murder charges.

title.children: Married couple accused of murdering teenage mother in 2002 plead not guilty

image.altText: Photo shows a part of the collection at White Silver Room inside Dresden's Green Vault where gold valuables hang

items.synopsis: A German court convicts five men over the theft of 18th-century jewels worth more than 100 million euros ($163 million) from a Dresden museum.

title.children: Five Germans sentenced for $163 million jewellery heist

image.altText: The top of the structure under water.

items.synopsis: Greenpeace has released underwater footage of Woodside's sunken riser turret mooring off the West Australian coast. The activist group says the structure is "decaying" and poses a contamination risk.

title.children: New video shows apartment-block-sized gas tower 'decaying' on the ocean floor, says Greenpeace
